Chapter 4: The Three Intermediate Eons, Section 11: The Three Intermediate Eons from the Sutra on the Cognition of the World
The Buddha told the monks:
There are three intermediate eons.
What are the three?
The first is the eon of warfare, the second is the eon of expensive grain, and the third is the eon of pestilence.
What is the eon of warfare?

In this world, people originally had a lifespan of 40,000 years, which gradually decreased to 20,000 years, then further decreased to 10,000 years, then decreased to 1,000 years, then decreased to 500 years, then decreased to 300 years and 200 years, and now the human lifespan is between 100 and 120 years.
After that, the human lifespan will gradually decrease to 10 years, and at that time, women will give birth at the age of five and get married.
At that time, all the delicious flavors in the world, such as ghee, oil, honey, rock candy, and molasses, all disappeared naturally, and the five grains did not grow, leaving only weeds.
At that time, all the fine clothes such as brocade, silk, cotton, and wool were no longer available, and only coarse grass clothes remained.

At that time, this land was filled with thorns, mosquitoes, bees, scorpions, vipers, poisonous insects, and gold, silver, lapis lazuli, the seven treasures, and precious stones all disappeared into the ground, leaving only stones, sand, and filth filling it.
At that time, beings only increased the ten unwholesome deeds, and no longer heard the name of the ten wholesome deeds, let alone those who practiced goodness.

At that time, those who were unfilial to their parents and disrespectful to their teachers and elders, and those who could do evil, would receive offerings and be respected by others, just as those who are filial to their parents, respectful to their teachers and elders, and able to do good, would receive offerings and be respected by others.
Those who did evil would receive offerings in the same way.
When those people died, they fell into the animal realm, just as people today are reborn in the heavens.
At that time, when people saw each other, they harbored thoughts of poison and harm, only wanting to kill each other.
It was just as a hunter sees a herd of deer, only wanting to kill them, without a single thought of kindness.
Those people were like this, only wanting to kill each other, without a single thought of kindness.

At that time, this land, with its ditches, ravines, valleys, hills, mounds, and mounds, had no flat land. When people came and went, they were terrified and frightened, with their hair standing on end.

At that time, for seven days there was a sword-warfare calamity. People held grass, wood, tiles, and stones in their hands, all turning into sharp swords. The swords were extremely sharp, cutting whatever they touched, and they harmed each other.

Among them, those with wisdom saw the mutual harm of the swords, and in fear they fled to the mountains, forests, ravines, and uninhabited places, hiding for seven days, and said in their minds and mouths:
'I will not harm others, and others should not harm me.'
For those people, during the seven days, they ate grass and tree roots to sustain themselves. After seven days had passed, they came out of the mountains and forests.
At that time, there was a person who met another person, and they joyfully said:
'Now I see a living person, now I see a living person.'
It was like a parent who had been separated from their only child for a long time finally meeting again, joyfully leaping and unable to contain themselves.
They were also like this, joyfully leaping and unable to contain themselves.
At that time, the people would cry and wail for seven days, and then for another seven days they would console each other, rejoicing and celebrating.
At that time, when people's bodies decayed and their lives ended, they all fell into the hells.
Why is it so?
It is because those people always harbor anger and malice towards each other, without any kindness or benevolence, which leads to the age of warfare.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
What is the age of famine?

At that time, the people often engage in unlawful activities, have inverted views, and commit the ten evil deeds. Because of their evil conduct, the heavens do not send rain, the grasses wither and die, and the five grains do not ripen, only the stalks remain.
What is meant by famine?
At that time, the people collect leftover grains from the fields, streets, and roads, and use them to sustain themselves, which is called famine.

Furthermore, during famine, people in the streets, alleys, markets, slaughterhouses, and cemeteries collect bones, boil them for juice to drink, and thus sustain themselves. This is called the famine of white bones.
Furthermore, during the famine kalpa, all the five grains planted turn into weeds and trees. At that time, people collect flowers, boil them for juice to drink.

Furthermore, during famine, the flowers and trees wither and fall, covering the ground below. At that time, people dig the ground, collect the flowers, cook them for food, and thus sustain themselves. This is called the famine of plants and trees.
At that time, sentient beings, when their bodies perish and lives end, fall into the realm of hungry ghosts.
Why is it so?

This is because during the famine kalpa, people always harbor greed and stinginess, have no mind of generosity, are unwilling to share, and do not think of those in distress. This is called the famine kalpa.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
What is the pestilence kalpa?
At that time, the people of the world practiced the right Dharma, had right views, and were not inverted in their views, and were endowed with the ten wholesome actions.

There were ghosts and spirits from other worlds who came, and the ghosts and spirits here were indulgent and licentious, unable to protect people, and the ghosts and spirits from other places invaded and harassed the people of this world, beating and whipping them, taking away their vital energy, causing their minds to be disturbed, and driving them away.
It was like when a king orders his generals to guard something, and thieves from other places come and invade and harass the people who are being indulgent, robbing villages and countries.
It was the same here, there were ghosts and spirits from other worlds who came and took the people here, beating and whipping them, taking away their vital energy, and driving them away.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:

Even if the local ghosts and spirits here are not negligent and licentious, powerful ghosts and spirits from other worlds will come. The local ghosts and spirits will be frightened and flee. Those powerful ghosts and spirits will harass these people, beating and striking them, taking away their vital energy, and killing them before leaving.
It is like a king or a king's minister sending out generals to guard the people. If the generals are pure, prudent, and not negligent,
there may be powerful generals from other places with many troops and soldiers who come to destroy villages and cities, plundering people and goods.

It is the same here. Even if the local ghosts and spirits dare not be negligent, powerful ghosts and spirits from other worlds will come. The local ghosts and spirits will be terrified and flee. Those powerful ghosts and spirits will harass these people, beating and striking them, taking away their vital energy, and killing them before leaving.
During the plague, when the people's bodies perish and their lives end, they are all reborn in the heavens.
Why is it so?
This is because the people of that time had a compassionate attitude towards each other and asked each other:ğŸ”½Are you well?
Are you in good health?
Because of this cause and condition, they were reborn in the heavens.
Therefore, it is called the pestilence kalpa.
This is the third intermediate kalpa.

After the fire calamity, when this world is about to form again, there are other beings whose blessings, practices, and lifespans are exhausted, and they die in the Ä€bhÄsvara Heaven and are reborn in the empty Brahma realm. After having this thought, there are other beings whose blessings, practices, and lifespans are exhausted, and they die in the Ä€bhÄsvara Heaven and are reborn in the empty Brahma realm.
At that time, the Brahma Heaven, which was born first, immediately thought to itself:

'I am the Brahma King, the Great Brahma Heaven King. No one created me. I naturally exist. I am not subject to anyone. I have the greatest freedom in the thousand worlds. I am skilled in all meanings. I am wealthy and abundant. I can create myriad things. I am the parent of all beings.'
The later Brahmas also thought to themselves:

'That earlier Brahma Heaven is the Brahma King, the Great Brahma Heaven King. He naturally exists. No one created him. He is the most revered in the thousand worlds. He is not subject to anyone. He is skilled in all meanings. He is wealthy and abundant. He can create myriad things. He is the parent of beings. We exist because of him.'
The Brahma King's appearance is always like a child. Therefore, the Brahma King is called the Child.

At that time, this world was being formed again, and many beings were born in the Ä€bhÄsvara Heaven, spontaneously transforming and being born, with joy as their food, their bodies emitting light, able to fly through the air with spiritual powers, blissful and unimpeded, with long lifespans.
Later, this world turned into a great body of water, covering everywhere.
At that time, the world was in great darkness, with no sun, moon, stars, day and night, and no years, months, or four seasons.

Later, when this world was about to change again, some other beings, whose blessings, practices, and lifespans were exhausted, passed away from the Ä€bhÄsvara Heaven and were reborn here, all born through transformation, with joy as their food, their bodies emitting light, able to fly through the air with spiritual powers, blissful and unimpeded, staying here for a long time.
At that time, there were no distinctions of male and female, high and low, or superior and inferior, and no different names. They were all born together in the world, thus called sentient beings.
At that time, natural earth essence emerged from the ground, coagulating on the ground like ghee. When the earth essence emerged, it was also like fresh butter, with a taste sweet as honey.
Later, a sentient being tried to taste it with their hand, knowing what flavor it was. Initially, they found it delicious and became attached to it.

In this way, they continued to taste it without stopping, and eventually gave rise to greed and attachment. They then scooped it with their hands, gradually forming lumps of food. As they continued to eat the lumps of food, other sentient beings saw this and imitated them by eating it as well. As they ate it without stopping,
at that time, these sentient beings' bodies became rough and their radiance gradually disappeared. They no longer had spiritual powers and could not fly.
At that time, there were no sun and moon yet. The radiance of sentient beings disappeared. At that time, the world became completely dark, no different from before.

After a long time, a violent storm blows the great ocean, which is 84,000 yojanas deep, causing it to part in two, and carries away the sun's palace, placing it halfway up Mount Sumeru, in the sun's path, circling the world.
The second sun's palace emerges from the east and sets in the west. At that time, some beings say:
'This is yesterday's sun.'
Some say:
'It is not yesterday's sun.'
The third sun's palace circles Mount Sumeru, emerging from the east and setting in the west. At that time, the beings say:
'It is definitely the same sun.'
The meaning of 'sun' is the cause of previous light, and therefore it is called 'sun.'
The sun has two meanings:
One is to always abide within its proper orbit, and the other is its palace.

The palace is seen from afar in all four directions, so it appears round. It is cool in winter and warm in summer. It is made of heavenly gold inlaid with crystal. Two parts are of pure heavenly gold, without any admixture, clear and transparent inside and out, with a bright light shining far. One part is of pure crystal, without any admixture, clear and transparent inside and out, with a bright light shining far.
The palace of the sun is fifty-one yojanas long and wide. The palace walls and ground are as thin as a catalpa tree.

The palace walls are sevenfold, with seven railings, seven nets, and seven rows of trees, all adorned with the seven treasures. The golden walls have silver gates, the silver walls have golden gates, the lapis lazuli walls have crystal gates, the crystal walls have lapis lazuli gates, the red pearl walls have agate gates, the agate walls have red pearl gates, and the various precious walls have vehicle-patterned gates.

Moreover, the railings were made of gold with silver crossbars, silver with gold crossbars, lapis lazuli with crystal crossbars, crystal with lapis lazuli crossbars, red pearls with agate crossbars, agate with red pearl crossbars, and various treasures with jasper crossbars.ğŸ”½Golden nets had silver bells, silver nets had golden bells, crystal nets had lapis lazuli bells, lapis lazuli nets had crystal bells, red pearl nets had agate bells, agate nets had red pearl bells, jasper nets had various treasure bells, and various treasure nets had jasper bells.

The golden trees had silver leaves, flowers, and fruits, the silver trees had golden leaves, flowers, and fruits, the lapis lazuli trees had crystal flowers and fruits, the crystal trees had lapis lazuli flowers and fruits, the red pearl trees had agate flowers and fruits, the agate trees had red pearl flowers and fruits, the jasper trees had various treasure flowers and fruits, and the various treasure trees had jasper flowers and fruits.

The palace walls have four gates, with seven steps each, surrounded by railings, towers, pavilions, gardens, forests, and bathing pools, arranged in pairs, producing various precious flowers, with rows of trees in proper order, various fruit trees with flowers and leaves of mixed colors, the fragrance of the trees pervading the four directions, and various kinds of birds singing harmoniously together.
The sun palace is held by five winds:
one is the holding wind, two is the nourishing wind, three is the receiving wind, four is the turning wind, and five is the regulating wind.
The main hall where the sun god resides is made of pure gold, sixteen yojanas high, with four gates to the hall, surrounded by railings.
The seat of the sun god is half a yojana long and wide, made of the seven treasures, pure and soft, like heavenly garments.
The sun god himself emits light that illuminates the golden hall, the light of the golden hall illuminates the sun palace, and the light of the sun palace shines on the four continents.
The lifespan of the sun god is five hundred years in the heavens, and his descendants continue in succession without interruption.
His palace does not collapse, lasting for one eon.
When the sun palace moves, the sun god has no intention of moving, saying, I move and abide, always enjoying the five desires and amusing myself.
When the sun palace moves, countless hundreds of thousands of great gods lead the way in front, joyfully without weariness, delighting in speed, and for this reason the sun god is called Swift.

The sun god's body emits a thousand lights, five hundred lights shining downwards and five hundred lights shining sideways. This is due to the merit of past karma, and thus there are a thousand lights. Therefore, the sun god is called 'One with a Thousand Lights.'
What is the merit of past karma?

Or there may be a person who makes offerings to Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as, helps those in poverty, gives them food, drink, clothing, medicine, elephants, horses, carriages, houses, and lamps, distributes them in a timely manner according to their needs, does not go against people's intentions, and makes offerings to virtuous and holy people who uphold the precepts.
Due to the causes and conditions of various innumerable Dharma joys and light, the good mind is joyful.
Just like when a ká¹£atriya king who is anointed on the head first ascends the throne, the good mind is joyful, it is also like this.

Due to these causes and conditions, when the body perishes and life ends, one becomes the sun god and obtains the sun palace with a thousand lights. Therefore it is said that good karma obtains a thousand lights.
Furthermore, why is it called the light of past karma?

Some people do not kill, steal, engage in sexual misconduct, speak divisively, harshly, or falsely, do not covet, harbor ill-will, or have wrong views. For these reasons, their wholesome mind is joyful.
It is like a large bathing pond at the crossroads, pure and clean. If someone traveling far, exhausted and thirsty, comes and bathes in the pond, they will be refreshed and feel joyful and delighted.
The ten wholesome deeds and the joyful wholesome mind are also like this.
When their body perishes and their life ends, they become the sun god, dwelling in the sun palace with a thousand lights. For this reason, it is called the light of wholesome karma.
For what other reason is it called a thousand lights?

There are people who do not kill, steal, engage in sexual misconduct, deceive, or drink alcohol. Due to these causes and conditions, with a wholesome and joyful mind, when their body perishes and their life ends, they become the sun god, residing in the sun palace with a thousand lights. For this reason, it is called the light of a thousand wholesome karmas.
Sixty moments are called one laya, thirty laya are called mahouta, and one hundred mahouta are called upama.
The sun palace moves south for six months, with the sun traveling thirty li. It never goes beyond JambudvÄ«pa to the south, and the same is true when the sun moves north.
What is the reason that the sunlight is so hot?
There are ten causes and conditions.
What are the ten?

First, outside Mount Sumeru there is Mount Khadira, 42,000 yojanas high, with a peak 42,000 yojanas wide, its circumference immeasurable, made of the seven treasures. For these thirteen reasons, the sun is called the 'thousand-rayed one.'
The light is clear and cool, spoken by the Buddha's sun.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
The lunar palace sometimes loses substance and wanes, and the light diminishes, so the lunar palace is called 'loss.'
The moon has two meanings:
One is to always abide by the proper distance, and the second is the palace.

Seen from afar in the four directions, it is round. Cold and warm are moderate. It is made of celestial silver and lapis lazuli. Two parts are celestial silver, pure and unadulterated, clear inside and out, with light shining far. One part is lapis lazuli, pure and unadulterated, clear inside and out, with light shining far.

The lunar palace is forty-nine yojanas long and wide. The walls and ground of the palace are as thin as catalpa wood. The walls are seven layers, with seven layers of railings, seven layers of nets, seven layers of jeweled bells, and seven layers of trees planted in rows, all decorated with the seven treasures, and so on, with countless birds singing harmoniously together.
The lunar palace is held by five winds:
The first is the holding wind, the second is the nourishing wind, the third is the receiving wind, the fourth is the turning wind, and the fifth is the regulating wind.
The main hall where the Moon Celestial resides is made of lapis lazuli, sixteen yojanas high, with four gates surrounded by railings.
The seat of the Moon Celestial is half a yojana long and wide, made of the seven treasures, pure and soft, like heavenly garments.

The Moon Celestial emits light that illuminates the lapis lazuli hall, the light of the lapis lazuli hall illuminates the lunar palace, and the light from the lunar palace illuminates the four continents.
The lifespan of the Moon Celestial is five hundred years in the heavens, and his descendants continue in succession without interruption.
Their palace is indestructible, lasting for an entire eon.
When the lunar palace moves, the Moon Celestial has no intention of moving, saying 'I am moving and dwelling,' always amusing himself with the five desires.

When the moon moves, countless hundreds of thousands of great devas always lead the way in front, delighting in it without weariness, delighting in its swiftness, and for this reason the moon deity is called Swift.

The moon deity's body emits a thousand lights, five hundred lights shining downwards and five hundred lights shining sideways. This is due to the merit of past karma, and thus the moon deity has this light, and for this reason the moon deity is called Thousand Lights.
What is the merit of past karma?

In the world, there are people who make offerings to Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as, giving food, drink, clothing, medicine, elephants, horses, carriages, dwellings, and lamps to the poor and destitute, distributing them in a timely manner according to one's needs, not going against people's wishes, and making offerings to virtuous and holy people who uphold the precepts.
This is precisely the various kinds of joy in the Dharma, the light of a wholesome mind.
It is like when a ká¹£atriya king, anointed on the head, first ascends the throne, and his wholesome mind is joyful, it is also like this.
For this reason, when the body perishes and life ends, one becomes the moon god, and the moon palace has a thousand lights. Therefore, it is said that good karma obtains a thousand lights.
By what karma again does one obtain a thousand lights?

In the world, there are people who do not kill, do not steal, do not engage in sexual misconduct, do not engage in divisive speech, harsh speech, false speech, or frivolous speech, do not covet, do not become angry, and do not hold wrong views. For this reason, the good mind is joyful.
It is like a large bathing pond at the head of a four-way road, pure and free from impurities. If a person traveling far in the heat comes to this pond, bathes, cools off, and feels joyful and happy,
the one who practices the ten wholesome deeds and is joyful with a good mind is also like this.
When that person's body perishes and life ends, they become the moon god, dwelling in the moon palace with a thousand lights. For this reason, it is called the good karma of a thousand lights.
By what causes and conditions again does one obtain a thousand lights?
There are people in the world who do not kill, steal, engage in sexual misconduct, deceive, or drink alcohol, and because of these causes and conditions, their minds are joyful.
When their bodies perish and their lives end, they become moon deities, dwelling in the moon palace with a thousand lights. For this reason, it is called the good karma of a thousand lights.
Sixty moments of thought are called one laya, thirty laya are called mahouda, and one hundred mahouda are called upama.

If the sun palace moves south for six months, the sun moves thirty li, and it never goes beyond JambudvÄ«pa to the south, then the moon palace moves south for half a year, and it never goes beyond JambudvÄ«pa;
The moon moving north is also like this.
For what reason does the moon palace diminish little by little?
There are three causes and conditions for the moon palace to diminish little by little:
First, when the moon emerges from the constellation Wei, this is one reason why the moon diminishes.

Furthermore, in the inner palace of the moon, the ministers wear blue garments, ascending in order, and the dwelling place is blue. Therefore, the moon wanes. This is the second reason why the moon wanes day by day.
Furthermore, the sun palace has sixty lights that illuminate the moon palace, eclipsing it and making it invisible. Therefore, the place that is eclipsed is where the moon is diminished.
This is the third reason for the waning of the moon's light.
Furthermore, what are the reasons for the gradual filling of the moon's light?
There are also three reasons for the gradual filling of the moon's light.
What are the three?
First, the moon faces the cardinal direction, and therefore the moon's light is full.

Second, the ministers of the moon palace all wear blue garments. The moon king sits in the middle on the fifteenth day to enjoy himself, and the light shines everywhere, blocking the light of the other heavenly bodies, and therefore the light is completely full.
It is just like in a group of lamps and candles, if one lights a large torch, it will block the light of the other lamps.
The moon god is also like this. On the fifteenth day, among the celestial beings, it obstructs the multitude of lights, and its light alone shines, also like this. This is the second cause.

Third, although the sun god has sixty lights illuminating the moon palace, on the fifteenth day, the moon god can use its light to shine back, causing it not to be obscured. This is the third cause for the full moon in the moon palace without any loss.
What is the reason for the dark shadow of the moon?
Because the shadow of the Jambu tree is in the moon, the moon has a shadow.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
The mind should be like the moon, cool and without heat. When going to the donor's house, be mindful and not distracted.
What is the reason for the existence of rivers?
Because of the sun and moon, there is heat. Because of heat, there is burning. Because of burning, there is sweat. Because of sweat, rivers are formed. Therefore, there are rivers in the world.
What is the reason for the existence of the five kinds of seeds in the world?
